item.title: NBA Schedule This Week: Your Guide to the Best Week 2 Games on TV
item.dc:creator: Alex Vejar
item.description:
CableTV.com’s NBA expert maps out the weekly TV schedule and breaks down the top games, key player matchups, and storylines so you know exactly what to watch.

The post NBA Schedule This Week: Your Guide to the Best Week 2 Games on TV appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
The first week of the NBA season was wild.

There were three instant-classic overtime games, and the Oklahoma City Thunder played in two of them. Multiple players had huge scoring nights of 40 or more. Zion Williamson yammed one on Victor Wembanyama. The Utah Jazz won a game.

Plus, there was plenty to talk about now that we’ve seen the fruits of the new NBA media deal.

If you’re an NBA devotee, here’s what you should be checking out during the second week of the 2025–2026 NBA season, and what I thought of some of last week’s TV and streaming experiences.

Jump to:

  • National NBA game of the week
  • NBA League Pass game of the week
  • NBA schedule this week
  • League news and analysis

National NBA game of the week

Golden State Warriors at Milwaukee Bucks | NBA TV

The Golden State Warriors kicked off the 2025–2026 season with two big wins over the Los Angeles Lakers and the Denver Nuggets, the latter of which was in overtime. Steph Curry looks great, Jimmy Butler hasn’t missed a beat, Draymond Green is making 3s, and Al Horford has fit in seamlessly.

The Milwaukee Bucks, though, have Giannis Antetokounmpo. They’ll be coming off a stretch of playing the Toronto Raptors and Cleveland Cavaliers on the road, and the New York Knicks at home. That’s a tough schedule for Milwaukee going into this game, which will be full of star power.

How to watch Golden State Warriors at Milwaukee Bucks
Date:
Thursday, Oct. 30
Time: 8:00 p.m. ET
Local channels: NBC Sports Bay Area, FDSWI
National channel: NBA TV
Location: Fiserv Forum, Milwaukee, WI

Stream on DIRECTV

Honorable mention: 

  • Dallas Mavericks vs. Detroit Pistons — Mexico City Game (Saturday, Nov. 1, 10:00 p.m. ET, Peacock).

NBA League Pass game of the week

Charlotte Hornets at New Orleans Pelicans | NBA League Pass

Yeah, yeah, I know. Neither the Charlotte Hornets nor the New Orleans Pelicans is gonna be playing for anything better than a spot in the Play-In Tournament. But I can’t ignore that two of the more exciting players in the NBA are facing off against each other.

LaMelo Ball is electrifying—the deep 3s, the passing, the overall flair. And Zion Williamson is healthy and looking trim to start the season. He even said he hasn’t felt this good since college.

It doesn’t even matter who wins this game. I just think watching those guys on the same court is worth the two-and-a-half hours.

How to watch Charlotte Hornets at New Orleans Pelicans
Date:
Tuesday, Nov. 4
Time: 8:00 p.m. ET
Local channels: FDSSE, GCSEN
Out-of-market: NBA League Pass
Location: Smoothie King Center, New Orleans, LA

Try League Pass

Honorable mention: 

  • Dallas Mavericks at Houston Rockets (Monday, Nov. 3, 8:00 p.m. ET).

What NBA games are on TV this week?

I feel pretty good about my recommendations for Week 2 of the NBA season. But if you’re not vibing with any of my picks, feel free to check out something from the TV schedule below. I mapped out the Week 2 schedule so you don’t have to spend precious time looking it up.

Data effective as of post date.

Swishes and airballs

Starting this week, this section will be dedicated to discussing things I thought were awesome (swishes) and what I thought sucked (airballs). Let’s get into it.

Swish: Inside the NBA. Watching EJ, Kenny, Chuck, and Shaq on TV again was like a warm hug. To top it off, they were exactly as I remembered them, which matters a lot.

Many, including me, had questions about whether Inside would be a shell of itself due to airing on ESPN rather than TNT. Not only was I totally wrong, but I also felt very delighted when the show ran a clip montage of Barkley bashing the Worldwide Leader (just before he heaped praise on it, but still).

It showed me that at least ESPN can make fun of itself a little bit, and that it’s committed (at least for now) to giving fans what they want.

Airball: Michael Jordan on the NBC broadcast. I might be out on an island on this one, but as soon as Jordan started saying how much he missed basketball and how he would lace ‘em up right now if he could and all that, I was out immediately. In a separate segment, he talked about load management. Are you effing kidding me?

A short, open letter to MJ: Basketball doesn’t need you anymore. We don’t need your get-off-my-lawn takes. We have plenty of those already, and they’re all annoying. Leave us alone.

Swish: The lounge setup in the NBA on Prime Video studio. If you didn’t see it, click that link. I might actually try moving in there, and I will fight whoever tries to stop me.

Airball(?): Peacock’s On the Bench thing. Mostly, it felt very similar to a regular broadcast—a play-by-play person supported by two analysts, with some interviews sprinkled in. I did like that, after timeouts, the analysts on the bench sometimes talked about what play a team would run. That felt slightly more in-depth.

But I was definitely distracted trying to figure out who was sitting next to the analysts during the game. Are they fans, owners, or something in between? Can they hear the analysts during the game? If they can, are they annoyed? Do they talk to each other during timeouts? I need to read journalism on this ASAP.

"So that whole timeout was allocated to that and me catching up with Larry Nance Jr." 🤣

Hear from Austin Rivers and Robbie Hummel during their first official "On the Bench" segment.

📺 Peacock pic.twitter.com/QiwOoHi5vJ

— NBA on NBC and Peacock (@NBAonNBC) October 27, 2025

Also, it was weird seeing the play-by-play announcer sitting by himself to start the game. It’s just not good TV.

So right now, I’m mixed on this. But I’m leaning airball.

Swish: The new NBA on NBC intro. Mainly for the change in aspect ratio. If you’ve been watching movies lately, you’d know that changing the aspect ratio has become a bit of a gimmick. In this case, though, man, it really works.

NBA schedule this week FAQ

When does the NBA season end?

The 2025–2026 NBA season ends Sunday, April 12, 2026.

How many games are in an NBA season?

The NBA season officially has 82 games. But since the addition of the NBA Cup, that number is technically 83 for the two teams that advance to the championship game of that tournament. The championship game doesn’t count as a regular-season game.

When is the NBA trade deadline?

The NBA trade deadline for the 2025–2026 season is February 6, 2026, at 3:00 p.m. ET.

Where can I watch Inside the NBA?

Inside the NBA will air on ABC and ESPN throughout the season. It will also include the show’s signature pregame and halftime shows.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com sports writer, Alex Vejar, is a passionate NBA fan who follows the league by watching multiple games per week. He analyzed the NBA schedule and made his viewing recommendations based on matchups, star power, style of play, and unique or interesting viewing experiences.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods for reviewing TV services.

Game day starts here!

  • How To Watch the NBA Without Cable
  • Best Streaming Services for Sports

item.title: NFL Schedule This Week: Your TV Guide to Every Week 9 Game
item.dc:creator: Taylor Kujawa
item.description:
Get ready for game day with our NFL TV schedule guide. We update this page weekly during the NFL regular season, so you can easily find kick-off times and channel listings for the week’s biggest matchups.

The post NFL Schedule This Week: Your TV Guide to Every Week 9 Game appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
It’s Halloween week, and the NFL season is hitting its stride as we barrel into November. The top teams are finally emerging and solidifying their dominance, led by the Indianapolis Colts and the powerhouse performance of Jonathan Taylor. As the calendar flips, this spooky week is the perfect time for a season-defining win or a loss that will haunt the locker room.

Week 8 was all about epic storylines. Taylor made another strong case for MVP by scoring three more touchdowns for the 7–1 Colts, while Jordan Love outdueled his mentor, Aaron Rodgers, in a thrilling Packers victory. Elsewhere, the Jets finally got their first win (on a Breece Hall trick play), and the Bills’ James Cook ran for a ridiculous 216 yards.

Week 9 is loaded, and sorting through kickoff times and channels can be a hassle. It doesn’t help that the NFL’s redesigned schedule page isn’t doing anyone any favors. So, I’ve put together a clear, scannable TV guide below to help you plan your week.

Jump to:

  • CTV’s NFL Game of the Week
  • NFL TV schedule this week

Bookmark this page. Stay updated with the NFL schedule all season by saving this page to your web browser.

Find the best TV provider for football

Enter your zip code below to see the top-ranked TV providers available in your area.

CableTV.com’s NFL Game of the Week

Kansas City Chiefs at Buffalo Bills | CBS, Paramount+

Coverage begins Sunday, November 2, at 4:25 p.m. ET: I hope you cleared your Sunday afternoon plans because this Chiefs–Bills game is a big one. The clash continues an intense regular-season history, marking the sixth consecutive year these longtime foes have met. But while this game historically impacts the race for the No. 1 seed, the stakes this year are about avoiding a Wild Card spot, as both the 5–3 Chiefs and 5–2 Bills are trailing their division leaders.

This matchup is a classic “strength vs. weakness” puzzle. The Bills’ clear path to victory is on the ground. I expect them to lean into the running game with Josh Allen and James Cook, attacking a Chiefs defense that’s been vulnerable against the run. If they can control the clock and keep Patrick Mahomes off the field, they have a great shot.

The problem is, the Bills’ defense ranks second-to-last in the league in rushing yards allowed per game. And they’ll be missing top pass-rusher Ed Oliver. That’s a bad recipe against an Andy Reid-coached team. Mahomes is again playing at an elite level, and with Rashee Rice back in the lineup, that offense is finally at full strength.

I have to give the edge to Kansas City here. The Chiefs have their mojo back, riding a three-game win streak and re-establishing themselves as an inevitable force. Fortunately, this is the marquee national game on CBS and Paramount+, so no one will need NFL Sunday Ticket to tune in.

Want more TV sports coverage?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest must-watch sporting events, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

NFL TV schedule this week

Every NFL regular-season game airs nationally except for the regional Sunday afternoon matchups on CBS and FOX. If you want live access to out-of-market games, you’ll need NFL Sunday Ticket or NFL RedZone’s whip-around coverage. All local and primetime games stream live on NFL+ for mobile device users.

Below is the complete list of NFL Week 9 matchups. You can also check out 506 Sports’ broadcast map to see which Sunday games will air in your region.

Game Date Time (ET) Channels
Baltimore Ravens at Miami Dolphins Thursday, Oct. 30 8:15 p.m. Amazon Prime Video
Chicago Bears at Cincinnati Bengals Sunday, Nov. 2 1:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
Minnesota Vikings at Detroit Lions Sunday, Nov. 2 1:00 p.m. FOX
Carolina Panthers at Green Bay Packers Sunday, Nov. 2 1:00 p.m. FOX
Denver Broncos at Houston Texans Sunday, Nov. 2 1:00 p.m. FOX
Atlanta Falcons at New England Patriots Sunday, Nov. 2 1:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
San Francisco 49ers at New York Giants Sunday, Nov. 2 1:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
Indianapolis Colts at Pittsburgh Steelers Sunday, Nov. 2 1:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
Los Angeles Chargers at Tennessee Titans Sunday, Nov. 2 1:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+
New Orleans Saints at Los Angeles Rams Sunday, Nov. 2 4:05 p.m. FOX
Jacksonville Jaguars at Las Vegas Raiders Sunday, Nov. 2 4:05 p.m. FOX
Kansas City Chiefs at Buffalo Bills Sunday, Nov. 2 4:25 p.m. CBS, Paramount+

Arizona Cardinals at Dallas Cowboys Monday, Nov. 3 8:15 p.m. ESPN, ABC, ESPN2, ESPN Deportes

Data effective as of post date. CBS and FOX games air in select markets.

Don’t miss your local NFL team in action

Enter your zip code below to find the best TV plans in your area that offer local and primetime NFL channels.

NFL Schedule This Week FAQ

What week is it in the NFL?

It’s currently Week 9 of the 2025 NFL regular season. We’re at the official halfway point, and the playoff picture is still a fascinating blur that’s slowly coming into focus.

Which NFL teams have a bye this week?

The Cleveland Browns, New York Jets, Philadelphia Eagles, and Tampa Bay Buccaneers are on a bye this week. After a 1–7 start, I’m sure the Jets are thrilled to get a breather.

Who is the best team in the NFL today?

This is a tough one because several NFL powerhouses are crowding the top of the field. The Indianapolis Colts (7–1) have the best record, but the Detroit Lions (5–2) just reclaimed the top spot in the NFL.com Power Rankings. Right behind them are the Kansas City Chiefs (5–3), Green Bay Packers (5–1–1), and Philadelphia Eagles (6–2).

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com Sports Editor, Taylor Kujawa, has been writing and refining this weekly NFL schedule guide since the 2022 season. Each week, he reviews the official league schedule and cross-references it with every broadcast partner. This process assures the channel listings for each matchup—including Spanish-language and alternate broadcasts—are always accurate.

Taylor’s “Game of the Week” selection comes from that hands-on experience, as he watches multiple games in their entirety every game week. His pick is a blend of on-field analysis (team performance, playoff stakes) and off-field expertise (broadcast accessibility). That dedicated, hands-on experience is what gives this TV guide a true fan’s perspective.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about CableTV.com and the methods we use.

Game day starts here!

item.title: How To Watch Survivor 49 Live on CBS and Stream on Paramount+
item.dc:creator: CableTV.com Staff
item.description:
Find out how to watch Survivor Season 49 live on CBS and stream every episode on Paramount+. Our guide covers the complete TV schedule and all the new twists!

The post How To Watch <em>Survivor 49</em> Live on CBS and Stream on Paramount+ appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
✦ Edited and fact-checked by Sports Editor Taylor Kujawa.

Will chaos reign? A look at Survivor 49

Since Season 41, Survivor’s “new era” has made its central goal keeping players off-balance. That intense, unpredictable spirit has fully spilled over into Survivor 49 even before the torches were lit.

Last season, we watched Kyle Fraser execute a highly effective game of social and strategic positioning. But if the premiere is any indication, Survivor 49 is going to be a glorious mess. The season is already fueled by unprecedented, chaotic energy, thanks to a historic, last-minute casting debacle that forced two alternates into the game just hours before the start.

The central question is whether these new castaways will lean into the disorder and make big moves, or if the desire to “keep the tribe strong” will lead to another set of predictable early exits.

The good news is that watching the madness unfold remains straightforward. Survivor 49 airs live every Wednesday night on CBS, with on-demand streaming available the next day on Paramount+. Here’s my complete guide on how to watch Survivor Season 49, so you don’t miss a single blindside or idol hunt.

Survivor Season 49 schedule and key updates

Host and executive producer Jeff Probst is back, of course, reminding us every episode that the show is always evolving. This season continues the 26-day, three-tribe format filmed in the Mamanuca Islands in Fiji.

The biggest headline kicking off the season was the last-minute cast shake-up. Two players were removed for communicating with each other before the game. This brought in alternates, meaning four total players on the beach are former standby contestants. That desperate hunger to play is going to inform every decision they make. Will they play too hard, too fast? I can’t wait to find out.

New episodes will continue to be a generous 90 minutes long, giving us more time for the social dynamics I live for. You can check out the full Survivor 49 TV schedule below. I’ll keep the table updated as the season progresses.

Survivor 49 weekly episode schedule

Episode # Day Time (ET) Channels
1 Wednesday, Sept. 24 8:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+ Premium
2 Wednesday, Oct. 1 8:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+ Premium
3 Wednesday, Oct. 8 8:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+ Premium
4 Wednesday, Oct. 15 8:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+ Premium
5 Wednesday, Oct. 22 8:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+ Premium
6 Wednesday, Oct. 29 8:00 p.m. CBS, Paramount+ Premium
7 TBA TBA CBS, Paramount+ Premium
8 TBA TBA CBS, Paramount+ Premium
9 TBA TBA CBS, Paramount+ Premium
10 TBA TBA CBS, Paramount+ Premium
11 TBA TBA CBS, Paramount+ Premium
12 TBA TBA CBS, Paramount+ Premium
13 TBA TBA CBS, Paramount+ Premium

Data effective as of post date.

Pro tip: To enjoy the full Survivor experience, you need to be able to watch live. Why? Because of the online discourse. The memes, the live reactions on Threads, and the deeper analysis on Reddit are all part of the fun.

If you don’t have cable, the most complete viewing option is a Paramount+ Premium plan. It gives you a live stream of your local CBS channel, so you can watch every tribal council in real-time. Paramount+ is also “the vault” for all 48 past seasons, making it the must-have service for the Survivor super fan.

Meet the tribes of Survivor 49

This season features 18 brand-new castaways divided into three tribes: Hina, Kele, and Uli. When the castaways were announced in August, I quickly began investigating each contestant for a thorough vibe check. Here’s a quick overview of the original tribes.

Hina Tribe: The underdogs with an edge

The Hina tribe is immediately interesting because it houses both of the last-minute replacements, Jason and MC, giving them a shared, intense starting point. Jason is a law clerk with self-proclaimed “little guy” energy and a keen mind for strategy. MC is a fitness trainer who only recently became a fan, so she’ll need to rely on her social game. The presence of Steven Ramm, a rocket scientist, and Matt Williams, an airport ramp agent, gives this tribe a great mix of brains and brawn. This group could easily become a tight-knit unit if they manage the chaos well.

  • Jason Treul (law clerk)
  • Kristina Mills (MBA career coach)
  • Matt Williams (airport ramp agent)
  • Michelle “MC” Chukwujekwu (fitness trainer)
  • Steven Ramm (rocket scientist)
  • Sophie Segreti (strategy associate)

Kele Tribe: The early-game strategists

The Kele tribe is already the talk of the town, albeit for frustrating reasons. They were the first to visit Tribal Council, voting out the perceived weakest physical player, Nicole Mazullo, over Kimberly “Annie” Davis. My first thought: Ugh. A boot over physicality is one of the most boring moves in the game.

The silver lining is the rest of the tribe: political comms director Alex Moore, correctional officer Jake Latimer (who missed the birth of his child to be here), and entrepreneur Sophi Balerdi, who is already on record wanting to use someone as a “meat shield.” There’s clear strategic potential here, but they need to shake off that early-game, challenge-focused thinking.

  • Alex Moore (political comms director)
  • Jake Latimer (correctional officer)
  • Jeremiah Ing (global events manager)
  • Kimberly “Annie” Davis (musician)
  • Nicole Mazullo (financial crime consultant)
  • Sophi Balerdi (entrepreneur)

Uli Tribe: The media-savvy contenders

I’m extremely high on the Uli tribe, which contains several media-savvy players who seem to understand the game’s narrative. Savannah Louie is a former reporter, and she’s already getting buzz for her savvy social game. Former Marvel Studios film producer Nate Moore is the closest thing this season has to a celebrity. If anyone understands how to shape a winning story, it’s him. Rounding them out is tech sales rep Rizo Velovic and clinical social worker Sage Ahrens-Nichols, who is one of the season’s original alternates. This tribe is packed with players who know how to control information, which could make them formidable post-merge.

  • Jawan Pitts (video editor)
  • Nate Moore (film producer)
  • Rizo Velovic (tech sales)
  • Sage Ahrens-Nichols (clinical social worker)
  • Savannah Louie (former reporter)
  • Shannon Fairweather (wellness specialist)

How to watch Survivor FAQ

How can I watch Survivor without cable?

You can stream new Survivor episodes live with a Paramount+ Premium subscription, or watch on demand the next day with a Paramount+ Essential plan. Alternatively, the show is available on live TV streaming services that carry CBS, or you can tune in for free using a digital antenna if you live near a CBS affiliate.

Is Survivor streaming on Hulu, Peacock, or Netflix?

No, Survivor is an exclusive CBS program, which means it primarily streams on the network’s proprietary streaming service, Paramount+. You won’t find episodes on Peacock or Netflix. But select episodes are available on Hulu (often via the Disney Bundle) and Paramount’s free streaming service Pluto TV.

Can I watch Survivor free on Amazon Prime?

No, Survivor doesn’t stream for free on Amazon Prime Video. You’ll need the Paramount+ channel add-on to stream episodes (past and present) of Survivor.

Where is Survivor filmed, and can I attend a live taping?

Survivor 49 continues the show’s tradition of filming in the Mamanuca Islands, Fiji. This marks the seventeenth consecutive season in this location. While the location provides beautiful backdrops, the show is filmed months in advance, and there’s no live audience.

The post How To Watch <em>Survivor 49</em> Live on CBS and Stream on Paramount+ appeared first on CableTV.com.

item.title: Your Ultimate Guide To Watching Liverpool FC in the US
item.dc:creator: Taylor Kujawa
item.description:
If you’re looking to watch Liverpool today, you’re in for another thrilling chapter of Reds football. The 2025–2026 season should be an exhilarating one under second-year head coach Arne Slot.

The post Your Ultimate Guide To Watching Liverpool FC in the US appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
If you’re looking to watch Liverpool today, you’re in for another thrilling chapter of Reds football. Last season was one for the ages, as head coach Arne Slot steered Liverpool to its 20th English league title. Sure, there’ll never be anything quite like Jürgen Klopp and his heavy-metal football. But LFC is still firing on all cylinders.

With Liverpool playing in multiple competitions, U.S. fans must navigate several viewing options to catch every match live. Premier League games air on NBC Sports platforms, while CBS Sports holds the U.S. rights to the UEFA Champions League. But that’s only part of the picture.

Below, I break down the best ways to watch Liverpool on TV in the U.S. From live TV services to streaming-only options, this guide covers everything you need to keep up with the Reds this season.

Jump to:

  • Liverpool FC channels
  • Liverpool TV schedule
  • Best Liverpool TV plans
  • LFCTV plans and prices

Want more TV sports coverage?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest event-viewing guides, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

What channel is Liverpool on in the US?

Liverpool TV channels vary game-to-game in the U.S. based on the competition. You’ll need NBC, Peacock, and USA Network for Premier League match days, while Paramount+ is a must-have for UEFA Champions League and EFL Cup (Carabao Cup) games.

FA Cup games stream on ESPN+. Let’s just hope Liverpool make it further than the Fourth Round this season.

Want coverage en Español? Select Liverpool EPL games air with Spanish-language commentary on Telemundo, UNIVERSO, and Peacock. Meanwhile, you can stream all Champions League matches in Spanish on ViX.

Upcoming Liverpool TV schedule across all competitions

And we’re off! With the FA Community Shield now in the rearview mirror, the 2025–2026 Liverpool FC season is officially underway. Get ready for a packed schedule, as the Reds will compete across four major competitions: the Premier League, Champions League, EFL Cup, and FA Cup.

Check out the TV schedule below for the next ten upcoming LFC fixtures and U.S. channel listings.

Opponent Competition Day Time (ET) Channels
Crystal Palace EFL Cup Wednesday, Oct. 29 3:45 p.m. Paramount+
Aston Villa Premier League Saturday, Nov. 1 4:00 p.m. USA Network
Real Madrid Champions League Tuesday, Nov. 4 3:00 p.m. Paramount+, Univision
At Manchester City Premier League Sunday, Nov. 9 11:30 a.m. USA Network
Nottingham Forest Premier League Saturday, Nov. 22 10:00 a.m. TBA
PSV Champions League Wednesday, Nov. 26 3:00 p.m. Paramount+
At West Ham United Premier League Sunday, Nov. 30 9:05 a.m. TBA
Sunderland Premier League Wednesday, Dec. 3 3:15 p.m. TBA
At Leeds United Premier League Saturday, Dec. 6 12:30 p.m. TBA
At Inter Milan Champions League Tuesday, Dec. 9 3:00 p.m. Paramount+

Data effective as of post date.

Best Liverpool TV plans for watching the most matches

Now that you know Liverpool’s U.S. TV channels and match schedule, it’s time to explore the best TV plans for watching the Reds.

Ultimately, you’ll need Peacock, Paramount+, and a live TV provider to tune in. But spending around $100 a month on TV services isn’t ideal for everyone. If that’s outside your budget, check the schedule above to prioritize the matches that matter most to you.

Peacock Premium ($10.99–$16.99/mo.)

Nearly half of the English Premier League’s matches stream exclusively on Peacock Premium, including several Liverpool games. In other words, there’s no way around this recommendation. You simply need Peacock if you’re a Liverpool fan.

The NBCUniversal streaming service carries 175 live Premier League games per season, including Peacock exclusives and NBC match simulcasts. But many matches will air on USA Network, which requires a cable, satellite, or live TV streaming service to watch.

One standout feature of Peacock is the ability to watch Premier League replays on demand for up to 30 days. It also offers league highlights, studio shows, and documentaries, making it a solid option for Liverpool fans to stay connected all season.

Paramount+ ($7.99–$12.99/mo.)

Paramount+ is a must-have for watching every UEFA Champions League game. Apart from the European Cup, the streaming service also carries live Europa League, EFL Cup, Serie A, and NWSL matches.

I’ve been a Paramount+ subscriber since day one, and its soccer coverage keeps me hooked. But there’s plenty to watch between match days, from hit movies to binge-worthy TV shows. Best of all, you can test it out with a seven-day free trial before deciding if it’s right for you.

Hulu + Live TV ($88.99–$99.99/mo.)

Beyond Peacock and Paramount+, you’ll need a live TV service to watch Liverpool games on USA Network. While Sling TV offers the cheapest access, I recommend Hulu + Live TV for its robust lineup of CBS Sports, ESPN, FOX Sports, NBC Sports, and TNT Sports channels. Plus, its convenient My Stuff watchlist lets you easily track upcoming games not on Peacock or Paramount+.

Hulu + Live TV also includes ESPN+ at no extra cost. That means you can watch all FA Cup, La Liga, and Bundesliga matches, along with select Women’s Super League games featuring Liverpool FC Women. And with unlimited DVR storage, you won’t miss those early-morning kickoffs in the U.S.

Level up your streaming experience!

Your internet must be as fast and reliable as Mohamed Salah to enjoy smooth streaming on game day. Enter your zip code below to find top internet providers in your area.

Everything you need to know about LFCTV

LFCTV is Liverpool FC’s official TV subscription service that features exclusive club content. In the U.K., it’s available as an add-on via Sky and Virgin Media, while U.S. fans can subscribe online through All Red Video (formerly LFCTV GO).

At just $6.49 per month, All Red Video offers one plan that includes full-match replays, extended highlights, behind-the-scenes features, and exclusive interviews. All you need is a free MyLFC account to get started—and you can score your first month free with promo code ARFREE25. All Red Video works via the LFCTV GO app on platforms like Roku, Amazon Fire TV, Android TV, and mobile devices.

In my experience, All Red Video shines brightest during the preseason, when it’s often the only place to watch live Liverpool matches. It’s also a reliable platform for streaming entire game replays without juggling multiple services. But it’s not super necessary during the regular season if you already have Peacock and Paramount+ subscriptions.

How to watch Liverpool FAQ

How can I watch Liverpool today for free?

You can watch Liverpool matches for free in a few ways, depending on the competition. Games airing on NBC or CBS are accessible with a digital antenna. Meanwhile, streaming services such as DIRECTV and Fubo offer free trials for watching matches on cable channels like USA Network or CBS Sports Network. Unfortunately, Peacock doesn’t have a free trial, but Paramount+ does.

Does Peacock have every Liverpool game?

No, Peacock streams less than half of Liverpool’s Premier League games live. You’ll need a TV provider that includes USA Network to watch the club’s other Premier League matchups.

How can I watch Liverpool’s FA Cup and EFL Cup games?

In the U.S., all of Liverpool’s FA Cup matches stream live on ESPN+. EFL Cup games are available on Paramount+ and may also air on channels like CBS Sports Network and CBS Sports Golazo Network.

How can I watch classic Liverpool matches on demand?

LFCTV offers full-match replays from the past 10 years, including select classic games like the iconic 2005 UCL Final. Additionally, you can find classic matches, highlights, and season reviews on YouTube for a closer look at Liverpool’s storied history.

What radio station is the Liverpool game on?

SiriusXM FC (ch. 157) carries live radio coverage of select Liverpool Premier League and Champions League matches in the U.S. You can also stream game day audio from Liverpool’s in-house commentary crew with a free MyLFC account or a paid All Red Video subscription. Heads up: BBC Radio 5’s coverage isn’t available in the U.S. without using a VPN to bypass territory restrictions.

Where can I watch Liverpool FC Legends games?

You can typically watch all Liverpool charity matches on All Red Video, while some LFC Legends games also stream on the club’s official Facebook page and YouTube channel.

Will Liverpool play in the US in 2025?

No, Liverpool won’t play in the U.S. this year, as the team will spend the bulk of its 2025 preseason in Asia. LFC typically alternates between Asia and North America for preseason tours. After visiting the U.S. in 2024, an Asia-based preseason seems the most likely for 2025.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com Sports Editor, Taylor Kujawa, compiled a list of all upcoming Liverpool FC matches and researched U.S. broadcast options. Using that data, he evaluated the best ways to watch Liverpool on TV in the U.S. based on game availability, pricing, and ease of use. Taylor then cross-referenced his findings with CableTV.com’s extensive sports and TV coverage to ensure accurate and reliable recommendations.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Game day starts here!

  • How To Watch Soccer
  • Best Streaming Services for Sports

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

To many, the UEFA Champions League (UCL) is the absolute pinnacle of club soccer. It’s where the best teams in Europe battle it out for continental domination, culminating in a championship match that’s a bigger global TV event than the Super Bowl.

The best part for U.S. fans is how simple it is to watch. Paramount+ is the exclusive home for complete English-language coverage, plus all Europa League and Conference League matches. Meanwhile, Spanish-language broadcasts are now split between TelevisaUnivision platforms (like TUDN and ViX) and the streaming service DAZN.

But what does that all mean for your wallet and your TV setup? To help you get ready for the next match day, I’ve outlined every way to watch the Champions League in the U.S. I’ve even included some free (and totally legal) viewing hacks.

Jump to:

  • Champions League channels
  • Champions League TV schedule
  • Best Champions League TV plans
  • Watch the Champions League for free

Want more TV sports coverage?

Subscribe to CableTV.com’s email newsletter for the latest event-viewing guides, entertaining takes, and money-saving promotions.

By signing up, you agree to our Privacy Policy & Terms and Conditions.

What channel is the Champions League on?

In the U.S., you can watch every UEFA Champions League game live on Paramount+. Select marquee matchups also air on CBS and CBS Sports Network.

Unfortunately, the Spanish-language U.S. broadcast rights are now broken up between TelevisaUnivision and DAZN. To guarantee access to every game, you’ll need subscriptions to both ViX Premium and DAZN. Traditional channels like Galavisión, TUDN, UniMás, and Univision also show some UCL matches en Español.

Looking for the UEFA Women’s Champions League? The great news is that the U.S. broadcast rights are just as simple. You can watch every single UWCL match with a Paramount+ subscription.

UEFA Champions League schedule

The UEFA Champions League operates on a long, wraparound schedule—beginning in late June one year and ending in late May the following year. But matches typically don’t air on TV in the U.S. until the league phase starts in September.

Here are the 2025–2026 season’s key dates to help you know when to tune in. For the most up-to-the-minute match schedule, I always recommend checking CBS Sports’ Champions League Schedule. I’ll also be updating this guide right here with the complete TV schedule as soon as we enter the knockout phase.

  • League phase: Sept. 16–18; Sept. 30 and Oct. 1; Oct. 21–22; Nov. 4–5; Nov. 25–26; Dec. 9–10, 2025; Jan. 20–21; Jan. 28, 2026
  • Knockout phase playoffs: Feb. 17–18 and 24–25, 2026
  • Round of 16: March 10–11 and 17–18, 2026
  • Quarterfinals: April 7–8 and 14–15, 2026
  • Semifinals: April 28–29 and May 5–6, 2026
  • Champions League Final: May 30, 2026

Best ways to watch the Champions League

  • Editor’s Choice: Paramount+ ($7.99–$12.99/mo.)
  • Cheapest en Español: ViX ($5.99–$8.99/mo.)
  • Best Live TV Service: Hulu + Live TV ($88.99–$99.99/mo.)

Score the best soccer coverage in your area

Enter your zip code below to find the best TV plans available for your home turf.

Pros

  • Every UCL match this season (in English)
  • Inexpensive pricing
  • Multiview feature for UEFA events (desktop only)

Cons

  • Small lineup of originals
  • No CBS Sports Network access

While Paramount+ is known for its on-demand library, it has also become an essential service for soccer fans like me. After all, it’s home to every UEFA Champions League, Europa League, and Europa Conference League match. On top of that, you also get domestic league coverage from the English Football League, NWSL, and Serie A, making it a powerhouse for global soccer.

What I love most is the value. Paramount+ is one of the most affordable streaming services out there, and every plan gets you the same great soccer coverage. You also get thousands of hit TV shows and movies, so there’s plenty to watch when your favorite teams aren’t competing.

For those looking for an even more robust experience, I recommend upgrading to the Paramount+ Premium plan. It gets you all the same great soccer, but with ad-free on-demand content and the entire SHOWTIME library. The biggest perk, though, is the inclusion of a 24/7 live feed of your local CBS station, which is a must-have for any college football or basketball fan.

View Paramount+ Plans

Pros

  • Inexpensive pricing
  • Extensive movie and TV show library

Cons

  • Only select Champions League matches
  • Clunky interface

For Spanish-speaking fans, my top recommendation for value is ViX. It’s important to know that TelevisaUnivision now sublicenses its Champions League rights to the more expensive DAZN streaming service. That means you’ll need ViX and DAZN for complete Spanish-language coverage this season. But for a fraction of the cost, ViX is still the most budget-friendly streaming option.

One of my favorite features of ViX is its free content. I recommend checking out the Deportes tab for the free Zona TUDN channel, which often has live UCL games and studio coverage. You can also enjoy tons of movies and shows without paying a dime.

To get the majority of the UCL matches on the platform, you’ll need a ViX Premium subscription. Those plans cost only $4.99 a month with ads or $8.99 a month without ads, and you can cancel anytime. A subscription also gets you a ton of other soccer matches from competitions like the Europa League, Liga MX, and the Leagues Cup.

View ViX Plans

  • Large channel lineup
  • ESPN+ and Disney+ included

Cons

  • Limited UCL coverage included
  • Expensive plans with frequent price hikes

If you’re a devoted fan of European soccer who wants one TV package that does it all, my top recommendation is Hulu + Live TV. While you won’t get every Champions League match in its base plans, its traditional channels (like CBS Sports Network, ESPN, and USA Network) will get you key UCL matchups and other soccer competitions.

What takes Hulu + Live TV up a notch is the fantastic value you get from the included Disney Bundle. That gives you complete, integrated access to ESPN+ alongside those key sports networks. But why does ESPN+ matter for Champions League coverage? Well, it unlocks every single La Liga and Bundesliga match—a massive win for any fan of Spanish or German soccer clubs.

To complete your Champions League coverage, you’ll still need the live games exclusive to Paramount+. Fortunately, you can add Paramount+ as a direct add-on through your Hulu account, which is great for streamlining your billing.

View Hulu + Live TV Plans

Still prefer cable or satellite TV?

You might be wondering, “Taylor, this is CableTV.com. Why are you only recommending streaming services?” Well, I’m glad you asked. For a soccer fan, streaming services offer more complete Champions League coverage than traditional TV packages. But the right cable or satellite plan will still get you the matchups that air on CBS and CBS Sports Network.

To see which TV providers are available at your address, enter your zip code below.

How to watch the Champions League for free

Get Free Local Channels
Editorial rating (4.5/5)
Recommended antenna:
Mohu Leaf 50 ($46.99, one-time purchase*)
Champions League channels:
CBS and Univision
Features:
All local broadcast channels
View on Amazon
Read Mohu Leaf review

*CableTV.com utilizes paid Amazon links. Amazon.com Price; $46.99 (as of 7/25/25 11:20 a.m. CT). Read full disclaimer.

There are a few ways to watch the UEFA Champions League for free. CBS Sports Golazo Network on Pluto TV streams select matches for free throughout the season, as does the Zona TUDN streaming channel on ViX. But if you want specific coverage, a Paramount+ free trial allows you to catch any UCL game within the trial period.

Another free viewing option is to use an over-the-air (OTA) antenna to pick up your local CBS or Univision station. While CBS doesn’t broadcast many UCL games, you still get crucial matchups—including the Champions League Final.

To determine if a CBS station is within range of your home, use the FCC’s Reception Map Tool by entering your zip code. Then, head to our Best OTA Antennas page to find an indoor or outdoor antenna suitable for your TV setup. I often recommend the Mohu Leaf 50, as its 60-mile range and amplifier technology are ideal for those in suburban areas.

Get free Champions League coverage on UEFA.TV

You can catch free UEFA content on the organization’s UEFA.TV streaming service. While you can’t watch live Champions League matches, you can view delayed highlights for free with a UEFA.TV account. The service also offers live coverage of UEFA’s youth and futsal competitions.

How to watch the Champions League FAQ

Can I stream the Champions League?

Yes, every UEFA Champions League match is available to stream live and on demand on Paramount+ in the U.S. You can also stream games on ViX and DAZN, plus any live TV streaming service offering Champions League channels like CBS, CBS Sports Network, Galavisión, UniMás, and Univision.

Is the Champions League only on Paramount+?

No, you can watch some UEFA Champions League matches on traditional channels like CBS and CBS Sports Network. DAZN and ViX also host Champions League coverage, as do Spanish-language networks TUDN, Galavisión, UniMás, and Univision.

Is the UEFA Champions League on Amazon Prime?

Yes, you can stream every UEFA Champions League game on Amazon Prime Video with the Paramount+ channel add-on. ViX Premium is also available as an add-on subscription, as outlined in our Prime Video Channels guide.

Can I watch Champions League matches at a bar or restaurant?

Yes, your best bet as a fan is to find a dedicated soccer pub in your area. But I recommend calling ahead to confirm they’re showing your specific match. For bar or restaurant owners, you cannot use a residential Paramount+ account to publicly show games. You must have a commercial subscription, like those offered through DIRECTV FOR BUSINESS.

How can I watch the Women’s Champions League?

Now through the 2029–2030 season, you can stream every game in the UEFA Women’s Champions League on Paramount+. The coverage starts each season from the league phase onwards, and select matches also air on CBS Sports Network and the free CBS Sports Golazo Network.

Which teams qualify for the UEFA Champions League?

Teams qualify for the UEFA Champions League based on their performance in their respective domestic leagues. Champions League and Europa League defending champions qualify for the league phase, as do the winners of the top 10 soccer associations in Europe based on UEFA country coefficients.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com Sports Editor, Taylor Kujawa, has been an avid fan of the UEFA Champions League for over a decade. He’s followed the competition across multiple broadcasters and has spent countless hours watching coverage since its move to CBS Sports in 2020.

For this guide, Taylor combined that firsthand experience with an in-depth analysis of every TV provider to find the most effective and affordable ways to tune in. He researched every channel and streaming platform and stays up with the match schedule to ensure his U.S. viewing recommendations are accurate and reliable.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Game day starts here!

item.title: How To Watch the 2025 MLS Playoffs
item.dc:creator: Taylor Kujawa
item.description:
It’s survival of the fittest as Major League Soccer (MLS) clubs fight for a place in the MLS Cup Final. The MLS Playoffs will air on MLS Season Pass and FOX Sports networks starting in October, with the grand finale in December.

The post How To Watch the 2025 MLS Playoffs appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
Stream on MLS Season Pass

I know some people out there think Major League Soccer (MLS) is the annoying stepchild of European soccer. But if you ask me, it’s the playoffs when these talented players really shine.

It’s survival of the fittest as clubs fight for a place in the 2025 MLS Cup Final. The MLS Playoffs will air on MLS Season Pass and FOX Sports networks from October to December, with the grand finale on Saturday, December 6.

This season, the playoffs continue last year’s format of 18 playoff teams. The top seven clubs from the Eastern and Western Conferences qualify for Round One, while the eighth and ninth seeds from each conference must first battle it out in the Wild Card Round.

Keep reading to see what specific channels you’ll need to watch the playoffs and how you can tune in for free.

Jump to:

  • MLS Playoffs channels
  • MLS Playoffs schedule
  • Watch the MLS Playoffs for free

Score the best TV provider in your area

Don’t miss a single minute of the MLS Playoffs. Enter your zip code below to see the top TV providers available for your home.

What channels are the MLS Playoffs on?

The 2025 MLS Playoffs will stream on MLS Season Pass, with select broadcasts airing on FOX and FS1. MLS Season Pass features English- and Spanish-language commentary, but Fox Deportes also shows playoff games en Español.

Pro tip: International MLS fans can watch the MLS Playoffs on MLS Season Pass, while select games will also air on TSN and RDS in Canada.

MLS Playoffs TV schedule

The 2025 MLS Playoffs begin with wild card matches on Wednesday, October 22, after what will surely be an exhilarating Decision Day on Saturday, October 18. As usual, the playoffs will feature intense action that culminates in the MLS Cup Final—set for Saturday, December 6.

Best TV plans for watching the MLS Playoffs

For my money, MLS Season Pass on Apple TV is the best way to watch the 2025 MLS Playoffs. At $14.99 a month or $9.99 for the remainder of the season, it’s an inexpensive viewing option for anyone with reliable internet. You also get in-depth studio coverage and on-demand access to every game—a great feature if you can’t tune in live.

If you prefer a more comprehensive TV provider, we recommend Hulu + Live TV because it comes with every FOX Sports channel and ESPN+. That’ll get you select MLS playoff games and live coverage of many other soccer leagues—including the German Bundesliga, La Liga, and the USL Championship. You’ll even get complete access to other marquee soccer tournaments like the NWSL Playoffs and FIFA Club World Cup.

Which TV providers offer MLS playoff channels?

If you prefer to browse more TV providers for playoff coverage, we outlined some of the most popular ones in the table below.

How to watch the MLS Playoffs for free

Get free local channels
Editorial rating (4.5/5)
Recommended antenna:
Mohu Leaf 50 ($46.99, one-time purchase‡)
MLS Playoffs channels:
FOX
Features:
All local broadcast channels
View on Amazon
Read Mohu Leaf review

CableTV.com utilizes paid Amazon links. Amazon.com Price; $46.99 (as of 7/25/25 11:20 a.m. CT). Read full disclaimer.

There’s no way to watch the entire MLS Playoffs for free. But some playoff games air on FOX, which is free to access if you live near a local network affiliate. You only need an over-the-air (OTA) antenna that’s strong enough to pick up the channel’s signal. Then, you’ll get every matchup on FOX—including the MLS Cup Final—without paying a monthly subscription.

Of course, the antenna itself isn’t free. But it’s a one-time purchase that will last several seasons and provide live sports year-round—including MLB, NFL, and Premier League games.

We recommend the Mohu Leaf 50 because its 60-mile range and included amplifier are ideal for clear channel reception. But you’ll first want to enter your zip code on the FCC’s Reception Map Tool to confirm a FOX affiliate is within range of your home.

If you require a wider-range antenna, visit our Best Antennas for Cord-Cutters page for more recommendations.

How to watch the MLS Playoffs FAQ

What channel is the MLS Cup Playoffs on?

The MLS Playoffs stream entirely on MLS Season Pass. But select playoff games also air on FOX Sports channels in the U.S., while TSN and RDS networks show some playoff matchups in Canada.

Where can I stream the MLS Playoffs?

You can stream every MLS playoff game on MLS Season Pass via the Apple TV app. Live TV streaming services that carry FOX and FS1 also provide access to select MLS games.

Does ESPN+ have the MLS Playoffs?

No, ESPN+ doesn’t have live MLS playoff games. Instead, you’ll need an MLS Season Pass subscription to stream the complete MLS Cup Playoffs.

Does Apple TV have the MLS Playoffs?

Yes, you can watch the MLS Playoffs on Apple TV with an MLS Season Pass add-on subscription. Select playoff games may also stream on Apple TV+.

Why you should trust us

Our CableTV.com sports editor, Taylor Kujawa, examined the best ways to watch the MLS Playoffs by comparing the prices and channel offerings of the most popular TV services. He selected his English- and Spanish-language viewing recommendations based on convenience—focusing on channel availability, pricing, and ease of signing up.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Hulu + Live TV is the best overall TV package for a complete soccer experience. It offers a wide array of channels that cover leagues like the English Premier League, Major League Soccer (MLS), and Serie A, with both English- and Spanish-language networks. Hulu + Live TV also includes ESPN Select at no extra charge, unlocking all games from the Bundesliga, La Liga, and the FA Cup.

For fans seeking even more European club soccer and women’s leagues, Paramount+ is an excellent complement. It offers top-tier competitions, including NWSL and the UEFA Champions League, alongside a wide selection of movies and TV series.

Not every league is on the same set of channels. If you’re looking to watch a specific team or competition, we’ll explain which channels and services will help you tune in.

Jump to:

  • Must-have soccer TV channels
  • Best TV services for soccer
  • Watch soccer for free

Get the best soccer coverage for your TV setup!

Whether you want a traditional cable or satellite TV service or need a more reliable internet plan for streaming, we’ll point you in the right direction. Enter your zip code below to find the best TV and internet providers available in your area.

What TV channel is soccer on?

The best soccer channel is the one that airs the games you want to see. But some soccer leagues are no longer accessible on traditional TV channels. In fact, you may need to sign up for a streaming service (or two) to watch your favorite team in action across all competitions. That’s why it’s essential that you know which competitions your favorite club participates in and where you must go to watch those games.

Best channels for watching soccer

  • beIN SPORTS broadcasts France’s Ligue 1, the African Cup of Nations, and the Turkish Süper Lig.
  • ESPN channels and ESPN Select cover the Bundesliga, La Liga, Emirates FA Cup, Scottish Premiership, United Soccer League (USL), Eredivisie, Indian Super League, and more.
  • FOX and FOX Sports channels FS1, FS2, and Fox Deportes broadcast major international soccer tournaments like the FIFA World Cup, FIFA Women’s World Cup, UEFA Euro, UEFA Women’s Euro, Copa América, and the CONCACAF Gold Cup.
  • HBO Max and Warner Bros. Discovery Sports channels TBS, TNT, and truTV are home to 20+ U.S. Soccer matches per year. The English-language coverage comprises USMNT and USWNT games, including World Cup qualifiers, friendlies, and special events like the SheBelieves Cup.
  • MLS Season Pass on Apple TV will get you every Major League Soccer and Leagues Cup game.
  • NBC, USA Network, CNBC, and streaming service Peacock Premium are the sole broadcasters of English-language Premier League coverage and the Olympic Games in the U.S.
  • Paramount+ is home to the UEFA Champions League, Europa League, and Conference League, as well as the English Football League (EFL) and Carabao Cup (EFL Cup). It also carries Italy’s Serie A and select matches from the National Women’s Soccer League (NWSL), Women’s Super League (FAWSL), and Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup. Additional CBS Sports coverage airs on CBS, CBS Sports Network, CBS Sports HQ, and CBS Sports Golazo Network.
  • Telemundo and UNIVERSO offer Spanish-language coverage of the FIFA World Cup, Olympics, and Premier League.
  • Univision and its sister channels Galavisión, TUDN, and UniMás have live Spanish-language coverage of the Champions League, Liga MX, and Liga MX Femenil. Additional TelevisaUnivision sports coverage streams on ViX.

Best TV services for watching soccer

  • Editor’s Choice: Hulu + Live TV ($88.99–$99.99/mo.)
  • Best Value: Paramount+ ($7.99–$12.99/mo.)
  • Best Sports Add-On: ESPN Select ($12.99/mo.)
  • Cheapest: Over-the-air antenna ($20.00–$60.00 one-time purchase)

Editor’s Choice: Hulu + Live TV

Editorial rating (4/5)
Price:
$88.99–$99.99/mo.
Soccer channels:
NBC, FOX, ESPN, ESPN Select, TNT, TUDN, and USA Network
Features:
Unlimited DVR storage and 95+ channels
View Plans for Hulu
Read Hulu + Live TV review

Data effective as of post date. Compatible device and internet connection required. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change.

Pros

  • Strong lineup of sports channels
  • ESPN Select and Disney+ included
  • Unlimited cloud DVR

Cons

  • Expensive plans
  • No beIN SPORTS channels

For the longest time, we recommended Fubo as the top streaming service for watching soccer in the U.S. It still boasts many soccer-oriented channels, but Hulu + Live TV has truly stepped up in recent years. (Interestingly, the Walt Disney Company plans to merge Hulu and Fubo soon, so we’ll see how that shakes out for soccer fans.)

What really wins us over about Hulu + Live TV is its comprehensive lineup. It includes every major sports channel that airs soccer, apart from beIN SPORTS, and even bundles ESPN Select and Disney+ at no extra cost. While Hulu + Live TV comes with a higher price tag, the inclusion of ESPN Select and Disney+ certainly sweetens the deal, offering unmatched value for a complete entertainment experience.

Through Hulu + Live TV, you’ll have English-language access to marquee Premier League, MLS, and FIFA World Cup matches. You’ll also get Champions League, Liga MX, and Leagues Cup matches en Español. But you may not get every game within those competitions.

If you want a little extra, Hulu also offers channel add-ons. These are especially great if your enthusiasm for sports extends beyond soccer (hello, NFL RedZone and Tennis Channel). But its Paramount+ with SHOWTIME add-on can take your soccer viewing to the next stage with additional soccer league coverage, as outlined in the next section.

View Hulu + Live TV Plans

Best Value: Paramount Plus

Editorial rating (3.9/5)
Price:
$7.99–$12.99/mo.
Soccer leagues:
UEFA Champions League, Serie A, National Women’s Soccer League (NWSL), Argentina Liga Profesional de Fútbol, and more
Features:
Large library of TV shows and movies
View Plans for Paramount Plus
Read Paramount+ review

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change. Compatible device and internet connection required.

Pros

  • All live Champions League games
  • Live World Cup qualifiers from select confederations

Cons

  • Limited sports and movies
  • Small (but growing) lineup of original shows

For under $10 a month, Paramount+ offers unbeatable value with the most European soccer coverage available. That’s because it’s home to every live game from the UEFA Champions League, UEFA Europa League, and UEFA Conference League.

Through these leagues, you will see Europe’s top soccer teams in one app. Paramount+ also carries English Football League, Serie A, Coppa Italia, and NWSL matches, as well as some CONCACAF and AFC competitions.

What separates Paramount+ from ESPN Select is that it’s not primarily a sports streaming service. That means you can also stream thousands of TV episodes and movies during the offseason or between matchdays of your favorite soccer leagues. You can literally go from watching Mo Salah score a worldie to Jean-Luc Picard trying to enjoy his retirement from Starfleet.

Paramount+ has two plans. Its Essential plan ($7.99 a month) comes with ad-based, on-demand content and doesn’t give you live TV streaming access to your local CBS station. On the other hand, its Paramount+ with SHOWTIME plan ($12.99 a month) has ad-free, on-demand content and in-app access to CBS and SHOWTIME.

No matter what plan you choose, you’ll have access to every sporting event unless it airs live on your local CBS channel (which you can watch via a digital antenna), so we recommend the Essential plan for $6.00 less a month—as long as you can stand the ads.

View Paramount+ Plans

Best Sports Add-On: ESPN Plus

Editorial rating (4.1/5)
Price:
$12.99/mo.
Soccer leagues:
Bundesliga, La Liga, Emirates FA Cup, Scottish Premiership, United Soccer League (USL), Eredivisie, and more
Features:
On-demand ESPN content and ESPN Select originals
View Plans for ESPN+
Read ESPN Select review

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change. Compatible device and internet connection required.

Pros

  • Plenty of live soccer and college sports
  • Rich on-demand library

Cons

  • No traditional ESPN channel access without TV provider login
  • Limited NFL and NBA coverage

ESPN Select (previously known as ESPN+) sits just behind Paramount+ when comparing soccer coverage per cost. While it works well as a standalone service, it truly excels in TV bundles or as an add-on, instantly expanding any TV plan with an immense library of live games from top international leagues and tournaments.

Two of the world’s top leagues, the German Bundesliga and Spain’s La Liga, receive exclusive coverage on ESPN Select. That means El Clásico and Der Klassiker are under the same roof. While select games from these leagues also air on ABC and ESPN, every game on ESPN Select has English- and Spanish-language options.

Pro tip: What do Robert Lewandowski, Baby Yoda, and June Osborne have in common? Probably not a whole lot, but you can watch all three of them when you bundle ESPN Select with Disney+ and Hulu for as low as $19.99 a month.

The major downside of ESPN Select is that you don’t get access to the traditional ESPN channels (ESPN, ESPN2, and ESPNews) alongside your ESPN Select content without a login from a cable, satellite, or live TV streaming provider. From a soccer standpoint, this means ESPN Select won’t give you every MLS and college soccer match because those leagues aren’t exclusive to the service the way some of the foreign leagues are.

If you’re looking for a TV provider to pair with ESPN Select, we recommend Hulu + Live TV or Sling TV for traditional ESPN access. Hulu + Live TV is a winning choice because it includes ESPN Select at no extra cost and has unlimited DVR space. But Sling TV’s Orange plan ($45.99/mo.) is a much cheaper option for getting ESPN and ESPN2, though you’ll need a separate subscription to ESPN Select.

View ESPN Select Plans

Cheapest: Over-the-air (OTA) HD TV antenna

Get Free Local Channels
Editorial rating (4.5/5)
Price:
Mohu Leaf 50 ($46.99, one-time payment*)
Soccer channels:
ABC, CBS, NBC, and FOX
Features:
All local broadcast channels
View on Amazon
Read Mohu Leaf review

CableTV.com utilizes paid Amazon links. Amazon.com Price; $46.99 (as of 7/25/25 11:20 a.m. CT). Read full disclaimer.

Pros

  • Low, one-time price
  • Local coverage

Cons

  • No out-of-market coverage
  • No DVR

At the bare minimum, you should invest in an over-the-air (OTA) antenna to watch soccer games that play on your local TV stations. An antenna is a one-time purchase that’ll give you access to several channels depending on your location and the antenna’s range. We like the Mohu Leaf 50 because of its 60-mile range and lightweight design. But we highlight several other great antennas on our Best OTA Antennas page.

Local channels carry some of the biggest soccer matchups, like the recent MLS Playoffs and the NWSL Championship. You can watch select Premier League games on NBC, while other league fixtures air on ABC and FOX. CBS is also a go-to channel for some Champions League and NWSL games.

A digital antenna also provides coverage to some of the world’s biggest sporting events, like the FIFA World Cup, the FIFA Women’s World Cup, and the Olympics.

How to watch soccer for free

If you’re looking for (legal) ways to watch soccer without spending a penny, you won’t find much more than extended highlights, replays, and analysis programs. Regardless, you can catch those on the following services.

  • FIFA+: Soccer’s highest governing body recently launched its streaming service for free. It includes 40,000 live matches per year and an archive with over 2,000 hours of content—including every men’s and women’s World Cup match captured on video.
  • Canela.TV: Canela Media’s free streaming platform offers live and on-demand Spanish-language programming. Some of its sports offerings are like other free services, but its Canela Deportes channel has unique and original coverage.
  • OneFootball: The soccer media platform includes a TV hub with free games from K League 1, the Danish Superligaen, and the Ukrainian Premier League.
  • Pluto TV: This free service has 200+ live and on-demand channels, including CBS Sports Golazo Network, CBS Sports HQ, beIN SPORTS XTRA, and FOX Sports.
  • The Roku Channel: Roku’s free live TV service recently broke the 200-channel barrier, and it features channels like beIN SPORTS XTRA, Fubo Sports Network, ViX (formerly PrendeTV), and Real Madrid TV.
  • Tubi: With nearly 100 live and on-demand channels, Tubi’s sports offerings include beIN SPORTS XTRA, FOX Sports, Fubo Sports Network, and Real Madrid TV.
  • ViX: TelevisaUnivision’s streaming service offers Spanish-language soccer coverage with free channels like beIN SPORTS XTRA en Español, Zona TUDN, Lo Mejor de Liga MX, and Lo Mejor del Futbol Europeo.
  • Xumo Play: This live and on-demand service has 190+ free channels, including beIN SPORTS XTRA, FOX Deportes, FOX Sports, and Fubo Sports Network.

How to watch soccer FAQ

Where can I watch soccer on TV?

You can watch soccer across channels like NBC, ESPN, FS1, and beIN SPORTS. Cable, satellite, and live TV streaming services feature many soccer channels, depending on your chosen plan. We typically recommend Hulu + Live TV for the best overall soccer coverage, but the service you choose really hinges on the teams you want to watch.

What soccer leagues does ESPN have?

ESPN shows select college soccer games and matches from the German Bundesliga and Spain’s La Liga. A separate subscription to ESPN Select provides even more soccer coverage, including all Bundesliga, La Liga, and FA Cup games.

What is the best streaming service to watch soccer?

ESPN Select is a fantastic soccer streaming service because it carries matches from the German Bundesliga, La Liga, and NCAA Division I. But Paramount+ is also necessary for its coverage of the UEFA club competitions, EFL, and Serie A, while Peacock is a must-have for any Premier League and Olympic soccer fan.

What is the best channel for soccer?

The best channel for soccer is the one where you can find the most action from your favorite leagues. Hulu + Live TV has most of the must-have soccer channels, but some leagues are specific to certain streaming services like Apple TV+, Paramount+, and Peacock.

Why you should trust us

Our soccer-crazed experts spent over 100 hours testing TV plans and streaming services to determine the best ways to watch domestic and international soccer. We evaluated each provider on several devices and compared prices, channel lineups, and league coverage.

To learn more about our methods, check out our How We Rank page.

Game day starts here!

The Canadian Football League (CFL) features eight teams battling from June to November for a chance to win the coveted Grey Cup. This season, stateside viewers can watch 34 regular-season games on CBS Sports Network. All remaining matchups will stream for free on CFL+.

Hulu + Live TV is the MVP service for watching the CFL because it has CBS Sports Network and many other channels for watching NFL and UFL games. The live TV streaming service also includes unlimited DVR storage and access to ESPN Select and Disney+ at no extra cost.

Our TV scouts have your full CFL viewing report below, including a closer look at CFL channels and key dates.

Jump to:

  • CFL channels
  • CFL TV schedule
  • Best CFL TV providers
  • Watch the CFL for free

Score the best CFL TV plan!

Enter your zip code to see your area’s top-ranked TV providers.

What channels show CFL games?

During the 2025 CFL season, you can watch games on CBS Sports Network and CFL+ in the U.S. This is the third year of the CFL’s broadcasting agreement with CBS Sports, but, unfortunately, no games will air on the main CBS Television Network.

For Canadian viewers, all CFL games air across TSN’s channels—including select Canadian French–language coverage on RDS and RDS2.

Want radio coverage? You can listen to every CFL game on SiriusXM satellite radio, with most games streaming on Canada Talks (ch. 167).

2025 CFL TV schedule: Key events and channels

From the CFL Draft in April to the Grey Cup championship in November, there’s loads of CFL action to observe each year. Below is a list of the most prominent CFL events this season, but you’ll want to check out the official CFL schedule for specific matchups and game times.

Event Start date U.S. channels Canada channels
2025 CFL Draft April 29, 2025 N/A TSN, RDS, TSN+

Cons

  • Small sports channel lineup
  • Only 2 simultaneous streams allowed

Hulu + Live TV is the best TV provider for watching the CFL because it’s one of the easiest ways to get CBS Sports Network.

With ESPN Select incorporated into Hulu + Live TV at no extra cost, you’ll get access to many other sports leagues in one place. That’s hard-to-find convenience, as sports leagues scatter games across various channels and streaming services.

If your football fandom extends beyond the CFL, Hulu + Live TV has all the essential channels for watching NFL, UFL, and NCAA college football games. After all, the ESPN channels alone are home to Monday Night Football matchups and over 40 college bowl games. ESPN2 even airs the Women’s Football Alliance (WFA) Pro National Championship game each summer.

With all that coverage, we’re happy to report that Hulu + Live TV also has unlimited cloud DVR storage space—a vital feature for any sports fan. The DVR allows you to record and hold onto any game, series, or movie for up to nine months.

  • Free access

Cons

  • On-demand access for only 48 hours
  • Limited device compatibility

It’s a no-brainer that you’ll need CFL+ to watch most CFL games this season. Introduced in 2023, the streaming platform is completely free and shows CFL on TSN broadcasts. But it has many limitations.

The first notable downside to CFL+ is that it’s accessible only on desktop and mobile devices using a web browser. In other words, don’t expect to find CFL+ on streaming devices like Amazon Fire TV, Apple TV, and Roku. But you can use Apple AirPlay to cast games onto your smart TV.

Even with access to CFL+, it’s a pretty bare-bones experience. On-demand replays expire after 48 hours (it’s better than nothing like last season), and there aren’t any studio shows or behind-the-scenes programs to enjoy when games aren’t on. You’ll want to bookmark the CFL’s YouTube channel for extra content.

Watch CFL+

Best Cable or Satellite Provider: DIRECTV

Editorial rating (4.1/5)
Price:
$89.99–$169.99/mo.*
CFL channels:
CBS Sports Network
NFL channels:
ABC, CBS, ESPN, FOX, NBC, and NFL Network
Features:
200 hr. DVR included
View Plans for DIRECTV
Read DIRECTV review

Data effective as of post date. Offers and availability may vary by location and are subject to change. See full disclaimer for details.

Pros

  • Over 20 basic sports channels
  • Wide regional sports network (RSN) availability

Cons

  • Expensive plans
  • 2-yr. contract for new DIRECTV customers
  • No NFL Sunday Ticket anymore

DIRECTV provides a robust TV experience for fans of Canadian and American football. The satellite service carries CBS Sports Network for CFL action, plus key NFL and UFL channels.

Beyond football, DIRECTV is a huge touchdown for sports fans because it offers most regional sports networks and out-of-network packages. That makes watching baseball, basketball, and hockey much more accessible, regardless of location.

In the long run, we recommend DIRECTV only to the most committed sports fans. There are many sports channels and packages to admire on DIRECTV. But Canadian football fans will still need internet access to get complete CFL coverage through CFL+.

View DIRECTV Plans

How can I watch the CFL for free?

Fortunately, the best part about the CFL’s latest broadcast plan is that viewers not based in Canada can watch many games for free. CFL+ streams select preseason games and over 40 regular-season matchups for free.

The only games U.S. spectators can’t watch for free are the ones that air on CBS Sports Network. But services like DIRECTV and Fubo usually offer free trials that allow you to access CBS Sports Network for a limited time without paying.

How can I watch the CFL in the US?

To watch CFL games in the U.S., you’ll need a TV plan that includes CBS Sports Network. You’ll also need online access to the free CFL+ streaming platform.

Hulu + Live TV is our favorite TV provider for watching the CFL because it has CBS Sports Network and includes ESPN Select for added sports coverage. It also has unlimited cloud DVR storage and comes bundled with Disney+ for bonus entertainment.

If streaming TV is not for you, we recommend DIRECTV and its massive channel lineups. The satellite service comes at a higher cost and includes a two-year contract, but you’ll get CBS Sports Network alongside other crucial sports channels. You’ll still need internet access for CFL+ to round out your CFL coverage, but you can explore some internet options in our DIRECTV Internet guide.

How to watch the CFL FAQ

Is CFL Game Pass available in the US?

No, CFL Game Pass no longer exists. But its successor, CFL+, is available in the U.S. and other countries outside of Canada.

Can I watch the CFL online?

Yes, you can watch CFL games on CFL+ and any live TV streaming service that carries CBS Sports Network. We recommend Hulu + Live TV because it has CBS Sports Network and includes ESPN Select for additional football coverage.

Are any CFL preseason games on TV?

Yes, select CFL preseason games stream on CFL+. In Canada, TSN and RDS also show preseason matchups.

Where can I watch the CFL in Canada?

If you’re located in Canada, you can watch English-language CFL coverage across TSN’s five channels. Select games with Canadian French–language commentary air on RDS and RDS2.

Why you should trust us

Our sports experts examined the CFL broadcast schedule to see which channels air games this season. We then spent over eight hours researching and testing TV providers to determine the best ways to watch every game. Channel offerings, pricing, and ease of use were key factors when deciding our provider recommendations.

Check out our How We Rank page to learn more about our methods.

Game day starts here!

item.title: What To Watch This Week: Stream Our Top 7 TV and Movie Picks (Oct. 27–Nov. 2)
item.dc:creator: Randy Harward
item.description:
This week’s “What To Watch” picks include The Witcher (Netflix), Hazbin Hotel (Prime Video), I Love LA (HBO Max), Down Cemetery Road (Apple TV), Shudder’s Trick or Treat Watch Party double feature, and more. Let’s hit the couch!

The post What To Watch This Week: Stream Our Top 7 TV and Movie Picks (Oct. 27–Nov. 2) appeared first on CableTV.com.
item.content:encoded:
CableTV.com’s fall TV preview guide is here!

Embrace cozy season with the best fall TV! The TV experts at CableTV.com have curated a list of top fall TV shows to help you find something to binge-watch while the leaves drop.

New on TV this week

This week’s “What To Watch” picks include the fourth season of The Witcher (Netflix), second season of Hazbin Hotel (Prime Video) and the debuts of I Love LA (HBO Max) and Down Cemetery Road (Apple TV).

We also recommend Shudder’s Trick or Treat Watch Party double feature (the classic 1978 slasher Halloween and acclaimed 2022 horror-comedy Deadstream), Robin Hood (MGM+), and Indera on video-on-demand (VOD). Let’s hit the couch!

Night owl? Peep what’s on late-night TV this week.

New on Apple TV+ this week

Down Cemetery Road | Apple TV+ | Thriller

Limited series, Wednesday, Oct. 29: In another Apple TV thriller series based on a Mick Herron book (the first being Slow Horses, now on its fifth season), a house blows up and a girl disappears. When the girl’s neighbor (Ruth Wilson) hires private investigator Zöe Boehm (Emma Thompson) to help find the girl, they stumble into a conspiracy. It seems that some supposedly dead people are still alive, while some living folks are dropping like flies. Two episodes stream today, with six more coming weekly on Wednesdays.

Read Our Apple TV+ Review

Pro tip: Do you believe truth is way scarier than fiction? Check out Sophie Hastings’ 5 True-Story Horror Movies That Hit Me Too Close to Home.

New on Prime Video this week

Hazbin Hotel | Prime Video | Adult animation, comedy

Season 2 premiere, Wednesday, October 29: In this very adult musical comedy series, Hell is overcrowded and Charlie, the princess of Hell, wants to deal with the problem non-violently. To that end, Charlie opens a rehab hotel where repentant Hell denizens can eventually get into Heaven. In the long-awaited second season, the hotel is booming but anti-Heaven sentiment is on the rise and the Vees wanna take it over.

Best Movies and Shows on Prime Video

See what to watch this weekend on all platforms

Click on your favorite streaming service below to see new releases and classic recommendations from our TV critics.

New on Netflix this week

The Witcher | Netflix | Fantasy, drama

Season 4 premiere, Thursday, October 30: In the fourth season of The Witcher, Henry Cavill’s out and Liam Hemsworth’s in as main character Geralt of Rivia. That has to bum some fans out, but Hemsworth looks pretty badass in the trailer. Also, fans would probably prefer swapping leads to ending the show before adapting the remaining books in Andrzej Sapkowski’s fantasy series. That’s happening, by the way—since a fifth and final season was filmed back-to-back with this one. Laurence Fishburne joins the cast this season.

Best Movies and Shows on Netflix

New on Shudder this week

Trick or Treat Watch Party: Halloween (1978) and Deadstream (2022) | Hulu | Horror

Double feature, Friday, Oct. 31, 9:00 p.m. ET: Trick or treat, smell my feet, gimme something good to watch! If you haven’t already planned what to screen at your Halloween party, this is a solid bet. You get John Carpenter’s terrifying classic 1978 slasher Halloween first, then the fantastic 2022 found-footage horror comedy Deadstream from Joseph Winter and Vanessa Winter. But if these don’t slash yer throat float your boat, we have 280+ horror movie recommendations—across nine different streaming services—in our 31 Days of Halloween Ultimate Streaming Guide.

Best Shudder Original Movies

Want more new TV shows?

« Catch Up on the Best TV Shows of 2024
Discover the Best TV Shows of 2025 »

New on HBO and HBO Max this week

I Love LA | HBO, HBO Max | Comedy

Series premiere, Sunday, Nov. 2, 10:30 p.m. ET: “An ambitious friend group navigates life and love in LA.” That’s it, folks. That’s everything HBO wants us to know about this series starring Rachel Sennott (Bottoms, Shiva Baby). So why recommend it? Call it a hunch. Or maybe it’s all about my English Teacher (FX, Hulu) fandom, because that show’s Jordan Firstman (delightful as Malcolm on the show) is also in the cast for I Love LA. Or maybe this show just seems like a coast-swapping, progressive Friends (which still sounds good despite my not really enjoying Friends). Expect one episode a week (eight total) through December 21.

Read Our HBO Max Review

Looking for your next binge-watch?

« Binge an Entire Show This Weekend
Start a Classic Binge-Worthy Show »

New on MGM+ this week

Robin Hood | MGM+ | Drama

Series premiere, Sunday, Nov. 2, 9 p.m. ET: The story of Robin Hood is only too familiar, but that doesn’t mean it can’t be souped up and reimagined. In Amazon Studios’ version, “Rob” (Jack Patten) grapples with inner demons while fighting the Norman elite (aka robbin’ from the rich, givin’ to the poor) in what the studio calls “a rich tapestry of historical accuracy, modern relevance, and intricate character dynamics.” Lauren McQueen and Sean Bean also star. We get two episodes today and the remaining eight will come weekly thereafter.

Read Our MGM+ Review

New movie releases available to rent/buy on VOD this week

Indera (2025) | Horror

In this Malaysian horror film, a man struggling to raise his non-verbal daughter takes a job as handyman for a woman who claims she can help the girl speak again—but with treatment comes terrifying visions for both father and daughter. You can rent Indera from video-on-demand (VOD) outlets like Prime Video, Google Movies & TV, and Fandango at Home (formerly VUDU) as of Friday, Oct. 31.

VOD releases this week

  • Seclusion (Oct. 28) Watch Trailer
  • Safe House (Oct. 31) Watch Trailer
  • The Wrecker (Oct. 31) Watch Trailer

« See Last Week’s Recommendations

The post What To Watch This Week: Stream Our Top 7 TV and Movie Picks (Oct. 27–Nov. 2) appeared first on CableTV.com.
